__data__.text: In the early days of radio broadcasting, two significant stations were WEAF and WJZ. During the initial phase of radio business consolidation, Radio Corporation of America (RCA) purchased WEAF from American Telephone & Telegraph (AT&T). This summary conveys the key points of the original text, discussing the importance of the early radio stations and the acquisition of WEAF by RCA from AT&T.

In the early radio era, WJZ and WEAF were prominent stations, with WJZ being a leading station owned by Westinghouse, a shareholder in RCA. Later, RCA, which had acquired WEAF from AT&T, and Westinghouse's WJZ formed a network, although not very organized at the time.

In 1923, WJZ was transferred from Westinghouse to RCA, relocating to New York City. Originally, WJZ belonged to Westinghouse, a shareholder in RCA, and WEAF to AT&T. Prior to this transfer, these stations formed an early radio network, although not highly structured. Initially, WEAF served as an experimental facility for AT&T's manufacturing branch, Western Electric, which produced radio transmitters and antennas.

In 1922, AT&T established WEAF as a research and development facility for Bell System, its telephone utility, to innovate audio transmission technologies, including voice and music, via short and long distances, through wireless and wired methods, complementing WJZ's early radio network activities.

In 1922, AT&T's WEAF, dedicated to advancing audio transmission technologies, became a popular radio station by airing a consistent series of programs, which included early instances of commercial sponsorships. A notable achievement of WEAF was its implementation of "chain" or "networking" broadcasting, as it successfully connected with WJAR, a station owned by Outlet Company in Providence, Rhode Island.

In 1923, AT&T's subsidiary, RCA, recognizing the benefits of sharing programming, obtained a license for radio station WRC in Washington, D.C. They aimed to transmit audio between cities by using low-quality telegraph lines, extending the "chain" or "networking" broadcasting concept, which was initially implemented by WEAF, to connect with WJAR in Providence, Rhode Island, and AT&T's station in Washington, D.C., WCAP.

In 1923, AT&T's subsidiary RCA utilized a licensed radio station, WRC, to pioneer the transmission of audio between cities through low-grade telegraph lines, while AT&T itself denied external companies the use of its superior telecommunication lines for networking broadcasting purposes. This approach aimed to interlink AT&T's station in Washington, D.C., WCAP, with other regional radio stations, such as WJAR in Providence, Rhode Island, thereby expanding the "chain" or "networking" broadcasting concept introduced by WEAF.

In 1923, RCA, an AT&T subsidiary, initiated city-to-city audio transmission through vulnerable telegraph lines, while AT&T refused to share its advanced telecommunication lines for networking broadcasting. This strategy aimed to connect AT&T's WCAP in Washington, D.C., with other local radio stations, like WJAR in Providence, Rhode Island, thereby advancing WEAF's "chain" or "networking" broadcasting idea. However, this early attempt faced challenges due to the telegraph lines' susceptibility to interference. By 1925, AT&T concluded that WEAF and its nascent network were not aligned with their main objective of offering telephone services.

In 1925, recognizing that their goals didn't align with WEAF's networking concept, AT&T decided to sell its radio station to RCA. This sale also granted RCA the right to rent AT&T's telephone lines for broadcasting networks, leading to the formation of the Red and Blue Networks. This move marked the end of AT&T's involvement in radio broadcasting and the beginning of RCA's expansion in the industry.

After selling their radio station to RCA in 1925, AT&T allowed RCA access to their telephone lines for broadcasting networks. RCA then bought WEAF and WCAP for $1 million, shutting down WCAP and merging WEAF's facilities with WRC. In late 1926, RCA established a new division, the National Broadcasting Company (NBC), which was a result of their acquisition and merger. This series of events marked the end of AT&T's participation in radio broadcasting and NBC's emergence as a significant player in the industry.

Following the sale of their radio station to RCA and their exit from the broadcasting industry, RCA established the National Broadcasting Company (NBC) in late 1926. NBC was formed through RCA's acquisition and merger of existing radio stations, with ownership divided among RCA (50%), General Electric (30%), and Westinghouse (20%).

After selling their radio station to RCA and leaving the broadcasting sector, RCA created the National Broadcasting Company (NBC) in late 1926. NBC was formed from RCA's acquisition and consolidation of existing radio stations, with RCA holding 50%, General Electric holding 30%, and Westinghouse holding 20%. NBC began broadcasting on November 15, 1926, with WEAF and WJZ, the primary stations of the two earlier networks, functioning simultaneously for around a year as part of the new NBC.

Following the establishment of NBC by RCA, the company split NBC's marketing strategies into two distinct networks on January 1, 1927. The "Red Network" focused on commercially-sponsored entertainment and music programs, while the "Blue Network" primarily transmitted non-sponsored broadcasts, specifically news and cultural programs.
The Red and Blue Networks' color designations at NBC originated from the pushpins' colors used to mark WEAF and WJZ affiliate stations or from the employment of red and blue double-ended pencils.

NBC established the NBC Orange Network, or Pacific Coast Network, on April 5, 1927, and later introduced the NBC Gold Network, or Pacific Gold Network, on October 18, 1931, extending their reach to the West Coast.

The NBC Orange Network, also known as the Pacific Coast Network, and the NBC Gold Network, or Pacific Gold Network, were established by NBC to expand their coverage to the West Coast. The Orange Network primarily aired content from the Red Network, while the Gold Network broadcast programming from the Blue Network. Initially, the Orange Network transmitted Red Network programming to West Coast stations, with KPO in San Francisco serving as the hub for this content.

In 1936, the Orange Network integrated with the Red Network, and the Gold Network merged with the Blue Network. Previously, the Orange Network had been linked to the Red Network, broadcasting its content to West Coast stations, while the Gold Network was associated with the Blue Network. NBC relocated to 711 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan in 1927, taking up space in a Floyd Brown-designed building. The summary captures the key points of the original text, conveying the changes in network affiliations and NBC's move to a new location.

By the 1930s, NBC had grown out of its Fifth Avenue location and created the NBC White Network for shortwave radio stations. Around the same time, General Electric, the parent company of RCA, had to give up NBC due to antitrust charges, leading to the development of separate networks. Initially, the Orange Network was connected to the Red Network, and the Gold Network was associated with the Blue Network. NBC's move to 711 Fifth Avenue took place in 1927.

After splitting from NBC due to antitrust charges, General Electric's subsidiary, RCA, signed leases in 1931 to relocate NBC's independent networks to the newly constructed Rockefeller Center, a deal facilitated by John D. Rockefeller Jr., the center's founder and financier, and RCA's president, David Sarnoff.

Upon moving to Rockefeller Center in 1933, RCA, having separated from NBC due to antitrust issues, took up the primary tenancy at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, then named the "RCA Building" (later changed to GE Building, now Comcast Building). This location also served as the home for NBC's production operations and RKO Pictures' theaters, as well as the iconic RCA chimes.

After splitting from NBC in 1933, RCA, now headquartered at 30 Rockefeller Plaza (originally called the RCA Building), introduced the famous three-note NBC chimes. These chimes, featuring a G-E-C' three-note sequence outlining a second inversion C-major triad, were first aired over WSB, an RCA Red Network affiliate in Atlanta. The chimes were also used by RKO Pictures' theaters at the Rockefeller Center.

Upon separating from NBC, RCA, based at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, debuted the well-known NBC chimes. The three-note sequence, which forms a second inversion C-major triad (G-E-C), was initially played over WSB, an RCA Red Network station in Atlanta. These chimes were also utilized by RKO Pictures' theaters in Rockefeller Center. An executive at NBC's New York head office, while airing a Georgia Tech football game, noticed the WSB version and sought authorization to broadcast it nationally.

After splitting from NBC, RCA, located at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, introduced the famous NBC chimes in 1931, which were first played over WSB, an RCA Red Network station in Atlanta. The three-note sequence, forming a second inversion C-major triad (G-E-C), was later adopted by NBC nationally after an executive at their New York head office heard the WSB version during a Georgia Tech football game. This tune became the first audio trademark registered by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office. A variant with an extra note, "the fourth chime" (G-E'-C'-G), was also developed.

After separating from NBC, RCA created the NBC chimes, initially aired over WSB in Atlanta. The three-note sequence, a second inversion C-major triad, was later adopted nationwide. A four-note version, known as "the fourth chime," was developed for significant urgent events, such as World War II and disasters. This "fourth chime" was the first audio trademark registered by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office.

Following its split from NBC, RCA introduced the NBC chimes, which were first broadcast over WSB in Atlanta and later became nationwide. The original three-note sequence, a second inversion C-major triad, was used for regular programming. However, a four-note version, known as "the fourth chime," was developed for critical emergencies like D-Day and disasters. This "fourth chime" was the first audio trademark registered in the US. In 1932, Rangertone founder Richard H. Ranger mechanized the chimes to transmit a consistent amplitude signal to NBC and AT&T's switching stations' engineers. The chimes' purpose was to serve as a low-level signal for these engineers.

After separating from NBC, RCA introduced the NBC chimes, initially aired on WSB in Atlanta and eventually adopted nationwide. The original three-note sequence, a second inversion C-major triad, was utilized for regular programming. A four-note version, known as "the fourth chime," was created for urgent situations like D-Day and disasters, being the first audio trademark registered in the US. In 1932, Rangertone's Richard H. Ranger automated the chimes to provide a consistent amplitude signal for NBC and AT&T's engineers, serving both as a low-level signal and a cue for switching individual stations between the Red and Blue network feeds.

The famous NBC chimes, initially aired on WSB in Atlanta and later adopted nationwide, were not originally designed to represent General Electric, despite popular belief. The three-note sequence, a second inversion C-major triad, was first automated by Rangertone's Richard H. Ranger in 1932 for consistent amplitude signaling and to signal engineers and network feed switching. The four-note version, known as "the fourth chime," was created for urgent situations.

The iconic three-note NBC chimes, which were automated for consistent amplitude signaling and network feed switching, continue to be utilized by the NBC television network, including in their NBC News theme music, despite the common misconception that they represent General Electric. The four-note version is used in urgent situations.

In the late 1930s, NBC permitted Baltimore & Ohio Railroad to use their well-known three-note jingle to signal meal times for train passengers, challenging the notion that the chimes represent General Electric. During this period, the Blue Network was rebranded as ABC, marking a significant shift in the broadcasting industry. The NBC chimes remained a consistent element in NBC's programming, even as the network's identity evolved.

The Blue Network, facing competition and complaint from the Mutual Broadcasting System regarding limited station establishment in a market dominated by NBC and CBS, was rebranded as ABC in the late 1930s, indicating a transformation in the broadcasting industry, while NBC retained its iconic chimes throughout its evolving identity.

The FCC launched a series of investigations in 1938 to examine the monopolistic impact of network broadcasting, and their report in 1939 concluded that NBC's two networks and their owned-and-operated stations held a dominant position in American radio, shaping audiences, affiliates, and advertising. This revelation contributed to the broader transformation in the broadcasting industry, which led to the rebranding of the Blue Network to ABC.

The FCC's investigations in 1938 revealed NBC's powerful influence over affiliates and advertising in American radio, prompting the commission to mandate RCA to relinquish ownership of either NBC Red or NBC Blue. Mutual's appeals were dismissed, and RCA subsequently challenged the divestiture order.

In 1941, as the FCC's investigation continued, NBC made the decision to sell NBC Blue Network, Inc. separately from NBC Red Network, Inc. in anticipation of a potential denial of their appeal, marking the formal division of the two networks.

In 1941, NBC decided to sell NBC Blue Network independently from NBC Red Network due to the ongoing FCC investigation, anticipating a possible rejection of their appeal. On January 8, 1942, the networks officially separated their operations, with NBC Blue being identified on-air as "Blue" or "Blue Network." Its official corporate name became Blue Network Company, Inc.

In 1942, NBC split its networks to address the FCC investigation, adopting different identities for each. NBC Blue was officially named Blue Network Company, Inc. and was referred to as "Blue" or "Blue Network" on-air, while NBC Red became known as just "NBC." The investment firm Dillon, Read & Co. played a role in this separation.

In 1942, Dillon, Read & Co. attempted to purchase NBC Blue for $7.5 million, but their bid was turned down by NBC executive Mark Woods and RCA president David Sarnoff. This rejection occurred despite the firm's previous involvement in the separation of NBC's networks.

In 1943, RCA sold NBC Blue to the American Broadcasting System, owned by Edward J. Noble, for $8 million, following the Supreme Court's approval in May of that year. This sale took place after Dillon, Read & Co.'s previous attempt to buy NBC Blue for $7.5 million was rejected by RCA and NBC executives.

In 1943, Edward J. Noble, through the American Broadcasting System, purchased NBC Blue from RCA for $8 million. The acquisition included the Blue Network name, leases on landlines, New York studios, and the rights to two-and-a-half radio stations: WJZ in Newark/New York City, KGO in San Francisco, and WENR in Chicago, which was shared with WLS. This sale occurred after Dillon, Read & Co.'s offer of $7.5 million was turned down by RCA and NBC executives, and followed the Supreme Court's approval in May of that year.

After purchasing NBC Blue in 1943, Edward J. Noble acquired the Blue Network name, leases on landlines, New York studios, and rights to two-and-a-half radio stations. Additionally, Noble secured contracts with actors and agreements with around 60 affiliates. To adhere to the FCC's radio station ownership rules, Noble sold his existing New York City station, WMCA.

Following the purchase of NBC Blue in 1943, Edward J. Noble obtained the Blue Network's name, landline leases, New York studios, and rights to a few radio stations, as well as securing contracts with actors and affiliate agreements. In 1944, Noble acquired the "American Broadcasting Company" (ABC) branding from George B. Storer to replace the Blue Network name. The transition to ABC was officially completed on June 15, 1945, after the necessary sale was finalized.

After acquiring NBC Blue in 1943 and renaming it ABC in 1944, Edward J. Noble established ABC as a significant radio network by obtaining the Blue Network's assets, securing contracts with actors, and maintaining affiliate agreements. NBC, during this time, featured numerous popular performers and shows, marking the radio's golden age.

Under Edward J. Noble's leadership, ABC emerged as a major radio network by taking over NBC Blue's assets, signing contracts with well-known performers, and preserving affiliate agreements. During this period, NBC was the home to popular stars such as Bing Crosby, Al Jolson, Jack Benny, Edgar Bergen, Bob Hope, Fred Allen, Burns and Allen, and the renowned NBC Symphony Orchestra, which NBC assisted Arturo Toscanini in creating. This highlights the radio's golden age, with NBC and later ABC hosting a multitude of famous personalities and shows.

During the radio's golden age, ABC (previously NBC Blue) also broadcast various popular programs, such as Vic and Sade, Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve, One Man's Family, Ma Perkins, and Death Valley Days, further enhancing their reputation alongside NBC's roster of famous personalities and shows.

During the radio's golden age, NBC had powerful stations, with some on unique clear-channel frequencies that reached vast distances at night, contributing to their strong reputation. Later, CBS, their competitor, started making progress by permitting their radio stars to establish and run their own production companies for programs, which turned out to be financially beneficial for many of their talents.

In the early phase of radio, it was common for stars and programs to switch networks when their short-term contracts ended. A significant shift occurred during 1948-1949, with numerous top NBC performers, such as Jack Benny, Edgar Bergen, and Charlie McCarthy, transitioning to other networks, which helped improve their financial standing. This movement marked a period of change and competition in the radio industry.

During the late 1940s, prominent radio stars like Burns and Allen and Frank Sinatra moved from NBC to CBS, enhancing their financial gains. Coinciding with this, NBC witnessed its radio stars, including the comedian Milton Berle, transitioning to television, with Berle's Texaco Star Theater becoming television's primary initial success. This period signified increased competition and transformation in the radio industry, with many personalities exploring new opportunities in television.

In the late 1940s and early 1950s, as prominent radio figures like Burns and Allen, Frank Sinatra, and Milton Berle moved to CBS and television, the NBC Symphony Orchestra, led by conductor Arturo Toscanini, also started broadcasting their concerts on both television and radio. This marked one of the earliest examples of simulcasting, as NBC sought to adapt to the changing media landscape.

In the late 1940s and early 1950s, the NBC Symphony Orchestra, led by Arturo Toscanini, made history by simulcasting their concerts on television and radio. Notably, they presented the first televised performances of Beethoven's Symphony No. 9 and Verdi's Aida, with Herva Nelli and Richard Tucker as soloists. These groundbreaking broadcasts took place without any scenic design or costumes, reflecting the orchestra's adaptation to the evolving media environment.

In the late 1940s and early 1950s, the NBC Symphony Orchestra, under Arturo Toscanini's leadership, made history by broadcasting their concerts on television and radio, aiming to maintain classical radio while television developed. They achieved this by airing performances without sets or costumes, distinguishing themselves from CBS's Sunday night radio lineup, which had absorbed many programs and talents from Jack Benny's defection. The orchestra's notable broadcasts included the first televised performances of Beethoven's Symphony No. 9 and Verdi's Aida, featuring Herva Nelli and Richard Tucker as soloists.

In the early 1950s, NBC introduced "The Big Show," a 90-minute variety program that refined radio's initial musical variety format by incorporating sophisticated comedy and dramatic elements. This launch followed the NBC Symphony Orchestra's successful classical radio broadcasts during television's emergence.

In the early 1950s, NBC introduced "The Big Show," a high-profile 90-minute variety program hosted by stage legend Tallulah Bankhead. The show attracted many esteemed performers, such as Fred Allen, Groucho Marx, Lauritz Melchior, Ethel Barrymore, Louis Armstrong, Ethel Merman, Bob Hope, Danny Thomas, and Douglas Fairbanks Jr., building on the success of NBC Symphony Orchestra's classical radio broadcasts during television's emergence.

In the early 1950s, NBC launched "The Big Show," a prestigious 90-minute variety program led by Tallulah Bankhead. Renowned artists like Fred Allen, Groucho Marx, Lauritz Melchior, Ethel Barrymore, Louis Armstrong, Ethel Merman, Bob Hope, Danny Thomas, Douglas Fairbanks Jr., and Ella Fitzgerald participated, leveraging the success of NBC Symphony Orchestra's classical radio broadcasts during television's rise. Although critically acclaimed, the show's popularity waned due to the growing number of television viewers, and it ended after two years.

The Big Show ran for two years, incurring approximately $1 million in losses for NBC as they struggled to sell ads outside of the show's middle segment. NBC's extensive radio programming efforts concluded with the 1955 launch of Monitor, following the decline of The Big Show due to increasing television viewership.

In 1955, NBC introduced Monitor, marking the end of their radio programming initiatives, after The Big Show suffered a two-year run with around $1 million in losses due to difficulties in advertising outside of the show's central segment. Monitor was the brainchild of NBC President Sylvester "Pat" Weaver, who was also responsible for the groundbreaking shows Today, The Tonight Show, and Home, intended for the companion television network.

In 1955, NBC launched Monitor, a pioneering all-weekend radio program led by President Sylvester "Pat" Weaver, marking the conclusion of their radio broadcasting endeavors. The Big Show had incurred significant financial losses, prompting NBC to shift focus. Monitor offered a blend of music, news, interviews, and features, utilizing prominent television figures such as Dave Garroway, Hugh Downs, Ed McMahon, Joe Garagiola, and Gene Rayburn as hosts.

In 1955, NBC introduced Monitor, a groundbreaking radio program led by Pat Weaver, which signaled the end of their radio broadcasting initiatives. The network decided to change focus due to the financial struggles of The Big Show. Monitor presented a mix of music, news, interviews, and features, employing well-known television personalities like Dave Garroway, Hugh Downs, Ed McMahon, Joe Garagiola, and Gene Rayburn as hosts. In an effort to preserve traditional radio, the program incorporated segments from Jim and Marian Jordan, known for their comedic roles as Fibber McGee and Molly, Peg Lynch's humorous dialogue Ethel and Albert (featuring Alan Bunce), and the satirical commentary of Henry Morgan.

For several years, Monitor prospered; however, from the mid-1960s onwards, local radio stations, particularly in major markets, became hesitant to deviate from their regular formats to air unconventional network programs like Monitor, which combined various elements such as music, news, interviews, and features. Notably, it showcased established television personalities and aimed to preserve traditional radio by including segments from renowned radio acts like Fibber McGee and Molly, Ethel and Albert, and Henry Morgan's satirical commentary.

In the midst of local radio stations' reluctance to air unconventional programs, Monitor had an exception with the weekly series "Toscanini: The Man Behind the Legend," which celebrated the renowned conductor's NBC broadcasts and recordings, and was broadcast for several years starting in 1963.

Once Monitor's 20-year run ended on January 26, 1975, NBC network radio mainly consisted of hourly newscasts, news features, and the Sunday morning religious program, The Eternal Light, indicating a decline in radio programming.

After the conclusion of Monitor's 20-year tenure, NBC Network Radio shifted towards limited programming, primarily consisting of newscasts, features, and the Sunday religious program, The Eternal Light. A shift towards revitalization occurred on June 18, 1975, with the introduction of NBC News and Information Service (NIS), offering extensive news coverage (up to 55 minutes per hour) available to local stations interested in adopting an all-news format.

Following Monitor's long reign, NBC Network Radio focused on news-related programming, such as newscasts, features, and the religious show, The Eternal Light. A change towards rejuvenation took place in 1975, with the creation of NBC News and Information Service (NIS), which provided extensive news coverage for local stations considering an all-news format. NBC broadcast NIS on WRC in Washington, D.C., and its own FM stations in New York City, Chicago, and San Francisco.

After launching NBC News and Information Service (NIS) to shift towards revitalization and offer comprehensive news coverage for local stations exploring an all-news format, NBC broadcast NIS on select FM stations. Despite attracting several dozen subscribing stations, NIS's profitability was not promising, leading NBC to announce its discontinuation in May 1977, giving affiliates a six-month notice.

In 1979, NBC introduced "The Source," a secondary network that delivered news and brief features to FM rock stations, experiencing moderate success. Additionally, the NBC Radio Network initiated a satellite-distributed national talk radio format, TalkNet, which debuted a popular evening talk show offering personal financial advice, hosted by Bruce Williams.

In the late 1970s, NBC Radio Network developed TalkNet, a satellite-based national talk radio format. Among its notable shows were Bernard Meltzer's financial advice program and Sally Jessy Raphael's personal and romantic advice show. Although TalkNet didn't gain high ratings, it played a significant role in advancing the nationwide talk radio format.

In the late 1970s, NBC Radio Network introduced TalkNet, a satellite-based talk radio format, which supplied struggling AM stations with free evening programming. This allowed local stations to air advertisements and maintain a flexible format without incurring production costs for local content. However, the growth of network-controlled programming sparked concerns within the industry about the potential centralization of radio content by networks and syndicators.

NBC Radio Network, under GE's ownership in the late 1980s, was marked for sale following GE's reacquisition of RCA. GE aimed to sell off RCA's non-broadcast assets and NBC's radio stations. An attempted sale of the entire radio unit to Westinghouse Broadcasting fell through, leading to the dissolution of NBC Radio Network's holdings. This development was in line with the growing concerns about increasing network control over radio content.

In the late 1980s, after NBC Radio Network's parent company, GE, decided to sell off its radio stations and RCA's non-broadcast assets, Westwood One, a syndicator based in Culver City, California, purchased NBC Radio Network, The Source, NBC Talknet, NBC Radio Entertainment, and the network's facilities' leases for $50 million. This acquisition occurred following the collapse of NBC Radio Network's sale to Westinghouse Broadcasting, which was in line with the growing worries about expanding network control over radio content.

In the late 1980s, NBC Radio Network was sold off in separate deals to various companies, such as Emmis Communications, Westinghouse, and Susquehanna Radio Corporation. This occurred after the proposed sale to Westinghouse Broadcasting fell through due to concerns about increasing network control over radio content. As a result of these transactions, Westwood One acquired NBC Radio Network, The Source, NBC Talknet, NBC Radio Entertainment, and the network's facilities' leases. In early 1989, Westwood One announced that NBC Radio News would relocate to Mutual Broadcasting System's facility in Arlington, Virginia.

In the early 1990s, NBC Radio News and Mutual Broadcasting System combined their engineering operations and affiliate relations department at Mutual's Arlington, Virginia facility. Additionally, during this time, both networks began jointly producing newscasts during overnight and weekend hours, and shared generic sportscasts throughout the weekend as part of their ongoing consolidation efforts.

In the mid-1990s, Westwood One acquired Unistar Radio Networks from Infinity Broadcasting, and in response, Infinity bought a 25% stake in Westwood One, making it the largest shareholder and gaining control over the company. This acquisition further intensified the ongoing consolidation in the radio industry.

After acquiring Unistar Radio Networks, Infinity Broadcasting became a major shareholder of Westwood One and took control of the company. Later, Infinity itself was purchased by Westinghouse Electric Corporation (which had merged with CBS/Westinghouse Broadcasting) for approximately $5 billion in 1996, the equivalent of $9.33 billion in 2022. As a result, CBS Radio Network became part of Westwood One's management. This series of acquisitions and mergers signified the continued consolidation in the radio industry during the mid-1990s.

Following its acquisition of Unistar Radio Networks, Infinity Broadcasting gained control of Westwood One. Subsequently, Infinity was bought by Westinghouse Electric Corporation (which had previously merged with CBS/Westinghouse Broadcasting) for around $5 billion in 1996, equivalent to $9.33 billion in 2022. This led to CBS Radio Network being integrated into Westwood One's management. In the context of these events, the Mutual/NBC newsroom in Arlington ceased operations on August 31, 1998, and CBS Radio News began producing "Mutual" and "NBC" newscasts from New York, reflecting the ongoing consolidation in the radio industry during the mid-1990s.

After Infinity Broadcasting acquired Unistar Radio Networks and was then bought by Westinghouse Electric Corporation, CBS Radio Network was integrated into Westwood One's management. As a result, the Mutual/NBC newsroom in Arlington closed in 1998, with CBS Radio News taking over the production of "Mutual" and "NBC" newscasts from New York. In 1999, these "NBC"-branded newscasts were limited to weekday morning drive times, while the remaining NBC affiliates were provided with CNN Radio newscasts during other time slots. This consolidation in the radio industry led to significant changes in programming and affiliations.

Following the integration of CBS Radio Network into Westwood One, the Mutual/NBC newsroom in Arlington closed and CBS Radio News began producing "Mutual" and "NBC" newscasts. In 2003, Westwood One, in collaboration with NBC News, introduced NBC News Radio, which offered brief newscasts on weekdays. This shift was a consequence of the consolidation in the radio industry, which brought about changes in programming and affiliations.

After the merger of CBS Radio Network and Westwood One, CBS Radio News started creating "Mutual" and "NBC" newscasts, and in 2003, they launched NBC News Radio with NBC-branded programs, including weekday news briefs presented by NBC and MSNBC anchors. The industry consolidation led to alterations in programming and affiliations. In 2004, Westwood One began simulcasting Meet the Press on audio, which continues to the present day.

After CBS Radio Network and Westwood One merged, CBS Radio News began producing newscasts for "Mutual" and "NBC," and in 2003, they introduced NBC News Radio with NBC-branded shows. Later, in 2007, Westwood One was acquired and combined with Dial Global, a subsidiary of Oaktree Capital Management, adopting the name Dial Global in 2011.

Following the merger of CBS Radio Network and Westwood One, CBS Radio News started creating newscasts for "Mutual" and "NBC," leading to the establishment of NBC News Radio in 2003. In April 2012, Dial Global ceased distributing CNN Radio newscasts and transitioned NBC News Radio into a full-time operation, causing most CNN affiliates to switch to NBC. After the 2012 collaboration between Dial Global and NBC Sports to establish NBC Sports Radio, the network stopped its 24/7 programming at the end of 2018 and was ultimately shut down in March 2020. In 2013, Cumulus Media bought Dial Global, which returned to the Westwood One name and integrated with Cumulus Media Networks, ending the NBC Sports Radio existence. In 1938, DuMont Laboratories introduced the initial home television sets, preceding NBC's entry into consumer electronics. This address was broadcasted through NBC's W2XBS Channel 1 (now WNBC) and reached approximately 400 viewers in the New York City area.
